content.webTitle: Republicans show support for criminal justice reform in rare bipartisan push

fields.headline: Republicans show support for criminal justice reform in rare bipartisan push
fields.bodyText: Conservative lawmakers voiced optimism about prospects for criminal justice reform on Thursday at a rare bipartisan event designed to build on political momentum following recent police violence. Presidential hopeful and Kentucky senator Rand Paul and Idaho congressman Raúl Labrador joined a number of senior Democrats at the Howard University panel convened in the wake of a string of controversial shootings, most recently in Charleston, South Carolina, and Tulsa, Oklahoma. Though shying away from commenting on the cases directly, both prominent Republicans said they were hopeful that broader legal reforms designed to reduce discrimination against African Americans were now gaining traction at both ends of the political spectrum. “One of the most exciting things in Congress is the right and the left – what I call the ‘wingnut coalition’ – is working together to improve justice in America,” said Labrador. Asked whether other Republicans would join his calls for sentencing reform and police body cameras, Paul added: “More Republicans are coming on. This is becoming a right [and] left thing.” Elijah Cummings, a leading African-American congressman who convened the meeting to address the “criminalisation, imprisonment and deaths” of Americans of colour, said: “Right now the nation is listening. Right now we have a moment to do a lot.” But whether the unusual alliance of libertarian-leaning Republicans and the Democratic black caucus can overcome congressional inertia is far from certain. Others on the panel questioned why the deaths of black Americans – whether as victims of crime or at the hands of police – did not attract more outrage across the US. “Some lives are more valuable than others,” said Stacey Plaskett, congresswoman for the US Virgin Islands and a former New York prosecutor. “The urgency does not seem to be felt in this country to deal with ugliness that does not have to be,” added New Jersey senator Cory Booker, who called for a national movement to match the suffragette and civil rights struggles. “Change does not come from Washington; it comes to Washington,” he added.
